nodes.bodyText:
I'm not sure if parameter object is the right pattern here. I suspect factory methods might be more appropriate.
We have two invocations of this method:
                .postTurnSummary(
                    (gameNameAndInfo + "\n\n" + turnSummary),
                    "TripleA " + title + ": " + currentPlayer.getName() + " round " + roundNumber,
                    SaveGameParameter.builder()
                        .path(saveGameFile.toPath())
                        .displayName(saveGameName)
                        .build());

                      "Test summary from TripleA, engine version: "
                          + ClientContext.engineVersion()
                          + ", time: "
                          + DateTimeUtil.getLocalizedTime(),
                      "Testing Forum poster",
                      f != null
                          ? SaveGameParameter.builder()
                              .path(f.toPath())
                              .displayName("Test.jpg")
                              .build()
                          : null);

Having the nullable parameter value is a big code smell.
I think the two APIs probably should be something more like:
              final CompletableFuture<String> future =
                  poster.postTestSummary();

And:
              final CompletableFuture<String> future =
                  poster.post(gameData, historyLog, saveGameFile);


The odd thing about a parameter object here is that it's not capturing all of the parameters. It's really just a value object.
It would also be cool to see some of this logic extracted yet further and then tested so we can avoid such a regression going forward.
I see your point. The reason I decided to implement it like this is to ensure that we don't end up in a state where for some reason one parameter is null and the other isn't

Makes sense, any thoughts to rename the object? Any thoughts on how we might be able to test this? I suspect the test decision would drive most of the rest of the choices.
Side-note, given we have save game in so many places, it's really quite the true violation of DRY.
